Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 29(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed his visitor visa and failed to attend initial proceedings; later attended with counsel.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of notice and denial of interpreter rights
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of immigration officer to issue exclusion order
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Proof of visa overstay, attendance records, representation by counsel, language comprehension
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: None found â€“ applicant understood English and was represented
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim of lack of notice not supported by evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Cancellation of removal order and procedural reconsideration
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No breach of procedural fairness; mandatory exclusion order under Regulation 228 due to overstay

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under subsection 29(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 29(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, missed initial proceedings, later attended with counsel; claimed lack of notice, interpreter issues, and ignored H&C factors.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Claims of inadequate notice, lack of interpreter, and failure to consider H&C
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of immigration officerâ€™s duty in procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Record of non-attendance, counsel representation, demonstrated English comprehension, absence of H&C referral requirement
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: H&C claims not substantiated or required at exclusion stage
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant understood proceedings; interpreter not necessary
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturn exclusion order based on procedural unfairness
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Mandatory exclusion for inadmissibility under subsection 29(2)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No obligation to provide interpreter when comprehension evident; H&C considerations separate from exclusion orders

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with residency obligation under section 28
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: section 28 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visitor visa and did not fulfill residency obligations; submitted H&C application but excluded from IAD referral
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant â€“ failed to meet residency obligation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to consider humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) factors
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority to issue exclusion without IAD referral when inadmissible solely for overstay
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa duration records, departure history, submission of H&C application
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: H&C factors not grounds to bypass mandatory exclusion under section 28
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No challenge to credibility; focus on legal applicability
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Exclusion order issued lawfully without IAD referral
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Set aside exclusion order and refer to IAD
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Procedural referral to Immigration Appeal Division
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Mandatory exclusion under IRPA when inadmissible solely for overstay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Section 28 requires exclusion order without IAD referral if inadmissibility is based solely on overstay

Crimes.Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness requires disclosure of report and opportunity to make submissions
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: No breach of procedural fairness found

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of admissibility and deportation order
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Disclosure of additional documents such as Highlights Report

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: None found â€“ no request for additional disclosure

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in referral and reporting process
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of CBSA admissibility report and referral
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: All transmitted information already known to applicant
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness does not require unsolicited internal documents
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No request for interview notes or explanations

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 44, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed their authorized period in Canada and were denied a visitor status extension. They requested an adjournment during their admissibility hearing to await processing of a humanitarian and compassionate grounds application.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign nationals with expired visitor status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Refusal of adjournment during admissibility hearing; constitutionality of s. 44 IRPA regarding separation of powers and procedural fairness
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review of immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa expiration dates, application for visitor extension, pending humanitarian and compassionate application
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of constitutionality of s. 44 IRPA and procedural fairness of refusal to grant adjournment
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Principles of procedural fairness and constitutional separation of powers
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Section 44 does not violate separation of powers; no breach of procedural fairness in refusing adjournment as humanitarian application was not guaranteed relief

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with residency obligation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 44, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants failed to leave Canada by the authorized date and sought an adjournment to await a decision on their humanitarian and compassionate grounds application.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent residents or foreign nationals subject to residency obligations
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of separation of powers and procedural fairness due to same department handling investigation and adjudication under s. 44 IRPA
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court's authority to review constitutional challenges to s. 44 IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Authorized departure dates, records of continued presence in Canada, submission of humanitarian and compassionate application
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review challenging constitutionality of s. 44 and fairness of procedural decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Constitutional principles of separation of powers and procedural fairness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: s. 44 IRPA is constitutional; administrative process does not breach separation of powers; no unfairness in refusing adjournment

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 2.03 and Section 76 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Application_Facts: Applicant did not receive email requesting additional documents due to technical issues; immigration officer failed to confirm receipt and ignored follow-up communications from counsel.
Procedural_Issue: Lack of adequate notice and opportunity to respond, failure to ensure communication was received
Evidence_Used: Email correspondence, records of communication attempts by counsel
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to verify receipt of critical communication, no confirmation mechanism used
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of application by a different officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness under Canadian administrative law
Decision_Rationale: The visa officer's failure to ensure the applicant received the request for documents violated procedural fairness, warranting remittal for reconsideration.

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of PRRA officer's assessment and need for interview on credibility
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 113(a); Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, s. 167
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, case referred for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer made adverse credibility findings based on past misrepresentations without interview
Crimes.Evidence_Type: New evidence of changed country conditions
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk due to perceived LTTE links and changed country conditions
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to hold interview despite serious credibility concerns
Crimes.Application_Error: Did not convene interview despite implicit credibility findings
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness for evidence, correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Potential credibility issues requiring oral clarification
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of false passport and prior false statements

Crimes.Crime_Name: Preventing Return as a Crime under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with removal order despite risk claims

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk due to changed conditions and LTTE association
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant subject to removal

Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Lack of interview despite credibility concerns
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: PRRA officerâ€™s authority to assess new evidence

Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient new evidence to support risk claim
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility based on prior misrepresentations
Crimes.Outcome: Referred for redetermination by another officer
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal, positive PRRA decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to address credibility through required procedures

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of negative PRRA decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in PRRA assessment and necessity of interview
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act s. 113; Regulations s. 167
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, referred for reassessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Adverse inference from prior false statements and use of false passport
Crimes.Evidence_Type: New evidence of changed country conditions and personal risk
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Perceived affiliation with LTTE and deteriorating conditions in home country
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Officer's failure to conduct interview despite credibility concerns
Crimes.Application_Error: Assessed credibility without providing opportunity for oral explanation
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of evidentiary assessment, correctness of procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Need for clarification on credibility through interview
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Duty to ensure procedural fairness in high-stakes decisions
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of document fraud and inconsistent claims
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of false passport during initial claim

Legal_Issue: Applicability of Article 1E of the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Governing_Law: United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees, Article 1E
Evidence_Type: Evidence of right to return to France
Basis_of_Claim: Claim for refugee status in Canada
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Holding rights and obligations akin to nationality in France
Assessment_Standard: Whether applicants were excluded under Article 1E based on residency rights in France
Application_Factor: Possession of French residency rights despite expired documents

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed past persecution but provided inconsistent information; economic motives inferred as primary reason for migration
Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of procedural fairness in assessment process
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, supporting documents (if any), timeline of events
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence to support persecution claim
Significant time elapsed since alleged events
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant's claims implausible due to inconsistencies and lack of corroboration
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no question certified
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of refugee status denial
Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to prove well-founded fear of persecution; credibility concerns and economic motivation undermined claim

Legal_Issue: Whether reasonable grounds existed to believe tax collection would be jeopardized by delay
Governing_Law: s. 225.2(2) of the Income Tax Act
Procedural_Stage: Review of ex parte jeopardy collection order
Evidence_Assessment: Assignment of Services MLM's most valuable asset to offshore company Wellgate with no Canadian assets
Burden_of_Proof: Crown must justify the jeopardy order; applicant bears burden to show lack of reasonable grounds
Credibility_Factor: Concerns over asset dissipation due to offshore transfer
Legal_Rule: A judge may authorize immediate tax collection under s. 225.2(2) if delay would jeopardize collection
Standard_of_Review: Reasonable grounds to believe jeopardy to collection
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of asset dissipation following transfer to offshore entity
Outcome_on_Merits: Jeopardy collection order upheld as justified
Key_Evidence_Considered: Transfer of assets to Wellgate, an offshore company without Canadian assets
Defendant_Response: Services MLM challenged the ex parte order, arguing lack of reasonable grounds and inadequate disclosure
Remedy_Requested: Review and cancellation of the ex parte jeopardy collection order
Outcome: Ex parte jeopardy collection order confirmed; challenge dismissed

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of natural justice due to non-disclosure of extrinsic evidence
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, case referred for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Marriage genuineness questioned based on inconsistencies and anonymous letter
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Anonymous letter, interview responses, supporting documents
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Duty to disclose extrinsic evidence under principles of natural justice
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged fraudulent marriage and failure to disclose relevant information
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness and fairness in administrative decision-making
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Applicant's consistent interview responses and documentation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Duty to act fairly and ensure natural justice

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of natural justice due to non-disclosure of extrinsic evidence alleging marriage fraud
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, case referred for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Authenticity of marriage doubted despite consistent applicant responses
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Anonymous letter, interview responses, supporting documents
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Obligation to disclose evidence affecting decision under natural justice
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged lack of cohabitation and genuine marital relationship
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Influence of undisclosed anonymous letter on decision
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Fairness and reasonableness in assessment of spousal sponsorship
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Supporting documentation and credible interview performance
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application rejected based on suspected fraud

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of duty to act fairly by failing to disclose relevant extrinsic evidence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Principles of natural justice and procedural fairness in Canadian administrative law
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Anonymous letter not disclosed but likely influenced decision
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate breach of fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Transparency and impartiality of decision-making process
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Extrinsic evidence relied upon must be disclosed to allow response
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Non-disclosure of anonymous letter questioning marriage legitimacy
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law principles governing procedural fairness
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review and re-determination by new officer
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, decision set aside
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Common law duty of fairness in administrative proceedings

Legal_Provision: Section 12, 14 of the Indian Band Election Regulations

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to investigate credible allegations of electoral misconduct
Governing_Law: Sections 12, 14 of the Indian Band Election Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: focused narrowly on direct exchange of alcohol for votes
Decision_Outcome: dismissed appeal due to insufficient evidence under incorrect standard
Burden_of_Proof: appearance of wrongdoing required, but higher standard applied
Legal_Rule: proof of appearance of wrongdoing suffices
Key_Evidence_Considered: investigator's report showing appearances of misconduct

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession and supplying of alcohol on a dry reserve
Governing_Law: s.14 of Indian Band Election Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: evidence of alcohol supply near election ignored due to lack of direct confirmation
Burden_of_Proof: appearance of wrongdoing standard not applied
Legal_Rule: appearance of wrongdoing sufficient under s.14

Crimes.Crime_Name: Contravention of Indian Band Election Regulations
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Provision_Involved: Sections 12, 14 of Indian Band Election Regulations
Grounds_for_Claim: corrupt practices including vote-buying and voter influence
Jurisdiction: First Nation elections under federal regulations

Crimes.Crime_Name: Corrupt practices in connection with an election
Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 12, 14 of Indian Band Election Regulations
Application_Facts: alleged use of alcohol to influence voters
Evidentiary_Deficiency: requirement for actual proof instead of appearance
Legal_Standard_Applied: incorrectly required proof of actual wrongdoing
Decision_Rationale: failure to apply statutory standard under s.14

Application_Facts: Applicant, Li Zhang, claimed residence from October 2, 2002; accumulated only 922 days of physical presence in Canada within four years before application, falling short of the required 1095 days.
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet minimum 1095-day physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenged the reasonableness of the Citizenship Judge's decision
Evidence_Used: Dates and records of physical presence in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient documentation or proof to establish 1095 days of residence
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application denied due to insufficient residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Residency requirement under section 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge correctly applied the law; no reviewable error was found. The qualitative test was not applicable because the applicant did not meet the physical presence threshold.

Dispute_Type: Housing allocation and transfer of tenancy rights
Legal_Issue: Whether Robin Roberts has a right to remain in the housing unit and is entitled to an injunction against eviction
Evidence_Assessment: Robin failed to provide concrete evidence of efforts to find alternative accommodation; no clear proof of irreparable harm
Burden_of_Proof: On Robin Roberts to demonstrate serious issue, irreparable harm, and balance of convenience
Credibility_Factor: Lack of documented efforts to secure alternate housing
Legal_Rule: (1) Serious issue to be tried, (2) Irreparable harm if injunction not granted, (3) Balance of convenience favors injunction
Grounds_for_Claim: Right to remain based on tenancy dispute within First Nation reserve
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed due to insufficient evidence and lack of legal justification
Key_Evidence_Considered: Claim of having nowhere else to go, lack of documentation on housing search
Legal_Framework: Injunction law under Canadian common law (RJR-MacDonald test)
Evidence_Type: Oral claims, lack of documentary evidence
Outcome: Eviction ordered; seven days to vacate, temporary restoration of electricity, no costs awarded
Legal_Provision: Common law principles governing interim injunctions

Crime_Name: Danger to the public under Immigration Act
Application_Facts: Townsend had a long criminal record and was initially declared a danger to the public; new evidence of rehabilitation was presented but the delegate reaffirmed the danger opinion based on seriousness of offenses and ongoing probation.
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of procedural unfairness in the reconsideration process
Evidence_Used: Criminal record, evidence of rehabilitation, status of ongoing probation
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the delegate's decision
Decision_Rationale: The delegate adequately reconsidered the case and provided sufficient reasons for maintaining the danger opinion, with due consideration of the seriousness of past offenses and current probation status.
Authority_Responsible: Minister's delegate under the Immigration Act

Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant's daughter was excluded from the family class under s. 117(9)(d) of the Regulations
Governing_Law: s. 117(9)(d) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Outcome: Daughter remains excluded from family class
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim of misunderstanding the declaration was not accepted; acknowledgment found valid despite signing errors
Basis_of_Claim: Failure to examine the daughter during the sponsorâ€™s permanent residence application
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant signed a declaration acknowledging the daughter would not be examined
Application_Error: Signing errors in the declaration, though not deemed material
Application_Factor: Non-examination of dependent child during principal applicantâ€™s immigration process
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Assessment of state protection and Convention grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicants' efforts to seek state protection inadequate despite credible testimony
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, country reports, applicant testimony
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee status due to blood feud in Albania
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Exhaustion of reasonable steps to avail state protection
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to properly assess adequacy of state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Specific applicant experiences regarding police involvement in blood feud cases
Crimes.Legal_Standard: State protection must be assessed case-by-case
Crimes.Application_Factor: Victims of blood feuds not automatically a particular social group
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD decision set aside and remitted for redetermination

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility assessment regarding false documentation and state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD doubted attestation letters due to potential falsification but accepted applicant testimony
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Attestation letters, applicant testimony, country conditions
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee status due to blood feud in Albania
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Efforts to seek reconciliation and adequacy of state protection
Crimes.Application_Error: Improper dismissal of reconciliation efforts and inadequate analysis of state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Applicantsâ€™ attempts to resolve the blood feud through formal and informal channels
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of potentially falsified documents in support of claim
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD decision set aside and remitted for redetermination
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Attestation letters deemed unreliable due to potential falsification

Legal_Issue: Whether the Director General breached the duty of fairness by not allowing the applicant to respond to objections
Evidence_Assessment: Failure to provide opportunity to respond to objections prior to decision
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate breach of procedural fairness
Legal_Rule: Duty of fairness may require providing parties an opportunity to address objections in administrative processes
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness simpliciter or correctness, depending on context
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of objections and lack of response opportunity
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, principles of natural justice
Defendant_Response: Director General proceeded with decision without addressing applicant's right to reply
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of decision via certiorari, costs
Outcome: Decision quashed, costs awarded to applicant, no referral back under s. 18

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 183 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Sodhi overstayed his visa, left Canada, and reapplied for a student visa; evidence showed attendance at Algonquin College after departure date.
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable â€“ decision based on non-compliance, not false information
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of procedural fairness in refusal
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of studies in India during gap period
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer questioned credibility due to academic attendance in Canada post-departure
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Certification of general importance and quashing of refusal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of visa officerâ€™s decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded re-entry without authorization based on applicant-provided evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Re-entering Canada without authorization under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Sodhi re-entered Canada illegally after deportation
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Transcripts and diploma indicated Canadian study post-2005 without valid status
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate lawful entry and compliance
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of documentation supporting studies in India or lawful re-entry
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicants must prove they entered Canada legally and will comply with visa terms
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in factual findings and procedural unfairness
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA sections related to admissibility and visa issuance
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Visa officer relied on applicant-submitted documents

Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Sodhi did not provide evidence of lawful status or explain presence in Canada after departure
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Deported individual reapplying for student visa
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: History of non-compliance with immigration status
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Implied omission of whereabouts and re-entry details
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Allegation that officer failed to give chance to respond to adverse inference
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Student transcripts, diploma, absence of Indian study records
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No documentation proving legal stay outside Canada or authorized re-entry
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant's explanation insufficient
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Visa refused due to credibility and compliance concerns
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: All evidence was provided by applicant; no procedural unfairness found

Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant faced persecution by OJI officers, who were state agents; lawyer contacted Ombudsman's Office without success; further attempts at state protection would increase danger
Procedural_Issue: RPD unreasonably concluded applicant failed to seek state protection
Evidence_Used: Credible evidence of persecution by state agents
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a new RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Presumption of state protection can be rebutted with clear and convincing evidence of state's inability to protect
Decision_Rationale: Persecution was carried out by state agents; requesting further protection attempts would place applicant in greater danger
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making a misrepresentation to obtain immigration benefits
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Interference of persuasive Board decisions with member's discretion
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim found to be economically motivated, not based on credible fear of persecution
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Economic motivation outweighed claims of persecution

Application_Facts: Applicant submitted a September 2002 UNHCR Report as new evidence in a PRRA application; the evidence was not reasonably available at the time of initial claim rejection.
Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer failed to explicitly address significant new evidence in decision, despite acknowledging consideration
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to reference or analyze the UNHCR report in written decision despite its probative value
Decision_Outcome: PRRA officerâ€™s decision found to be unreasonable due to inadequate consideration of evidence
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of PRRA by a different officer
Decision_Rationale: New evidence under IRPA s.113(a) must be meaningfully considered; omission constitutes reviewable error

Application_Facts: Judge reviewed documents and stated satisfaction with residency criteria without detailed analysis
Residency_Compliance: Assessed as compliant, but without sufficient reasoning
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide clear and detailed reasons for decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of reference to specific evidence or analysis of documents
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by a different Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory duty to provide adequate reasons
Decision_Rationale: Reasons were too brief and failed to demonstrate application of correct legal test or consideration of all facts

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee status criteria
Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA and Regulations - Refugee and Humanitarian Protection Criteria
Application_Facts: Mayelli Kamara fled Sierra Leone due to civil war; claimed need for refugee status or humanitarian protection; children included in application
Claimant_Status: Applicant for refugee status under Convention refugees abroad class or country of asylum class
Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of procedural fairness in visa officer's assessment
Evidence_Used: Country condition reports on post-conflict Sierra Leone
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence demonstrating targeted persecution
Insufficient proof of ongoing risk upon return
Credibility_Assessment: Visa officer found applicant did not credibly demonstrate individualized risk or persecution
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's refusal
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of refusal decision and grant of protected person status
Legal_Standard_Applied: Definition of Convention refugee and country of asylum class
Decision_Rationale: No evidence of targeted persecution; post-conflict conditions in Sierra Leone allow for safe repatriation; no durable solution issues established
Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of a Narcotic for the Purpose of Trafficking
Application_Facts: Applicant was convicted of heroin trafficking; panel excluded from refugee status based on drug conviction
Procedural_Issue: Panel may have erred in legal interpretation
Jurisdictional_Issue: Question of whether Refugee Division had proper jurisdiction under Article 1(F)(c)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider Supreme Court precedent (Pushpanathan)
Outcome: Panel's decision set aside; matter remitted to Refugee Division
Legal_Standard_Applied: Article 1(F)(c) â€“ acts contrary to UN purposes and principles
Decision_Rationale: Drug offenses alone do not meet threshold of violating UN principles per Supreme Court

Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection under international law
Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Potential failure to apply binding precedent
Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Supreme Court precedent (Pushpanathan) not properly considered
Decision_Outcome: Initial denial of refugee status based on criminal conviction
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Alleged exclusion under Article 1(F)(c) due to drug trafficking
Outcome: Decision set aside; applicant to be reconsidered for Convention refugee status
Basis_for_Decision: Drug trafficking not inherently contrary to UN principles per Pushpanathan
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to follow binding Supreme Court interpretation

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Decision_Outcome: The Board erred in its determination; the case was remitted for redetermination
Institutional_Action: Refugee claim rejected by the Refugee Protection Division

Evidence_Sufficiency: Board failed to assess sufficiency properly

Governing_Law: UN Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Raina convicted of indecent assault in New Zealand, sought refugee status in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to apply equivalency tests
Jurisdictional_Issue: Assessment of foreign conviction under Canadian law
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to apply statutory comparison, evidence sufficiency, or combined test for equivalency
Decision_Outcome: Exclusion from refugee protection set aside
Legal_Standard_Applied: Equivalency of foreign crimes to Canadian offenses
Decision_Rationale: Error in assuming equivalency without proper test; improper use of acquitted charge

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to provide necessaries of life (negligence claim dismissed)
Application_Facts: Inmate injured during an assault and claimed negligence due to delayed medical attention.
Procedural_Issue: Trial focused on whether the defendant breached duty of care; causation deferred to second phase.
Decision_Outcome: Action dismissed with costs to the defendant.
Outcome: No breach of duty of care found.
Legal_Standard_Applied: The Crown is vicariously liable for negligence if an officer, acting within employment scope, fails to meet the standard of care expected of a reasonable person.
Decision_Rationale: No evidence that corrections officers acted below the standard of care. The plaintiffâ€™s condition was not visibly obvious, and multiple checks were conducted without signs of distress.

Application_Facts: Inmate assault leading to Bastarache's injury and subsequent negligence claim against prison staff.
Procedural_Issue: Trial focused on whether prison staff breached duty of care; bifurcated trial separated liability and damages.
Decision_Outcome: Action dismissed with costs to defendant.
Outcome: No breach of duty of care occurred.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Prison authorities owe a duty of care to inmates, requiring reasonable measures to ensure their health and safety.
Decision_Rationale: Bastarache was injured but concealed it, locking his cell. Officers conducted regular checks without noticing distress. No evidence shows officers acted below the standard of care.

Decision_Outcome: Action dismissed with costs fixed at $1,500 payable by plaintiff to defendant.
Criminal_Activity: Inmate assault leading to severe injury and subsequent negligence claim against prison officials.
Outcome: No breach of duty occurred as officers acted reasonably given the circumstances.
Basis_for_Decision: Bastarache was injured but concealed it, locking his cell after refusing medical attention. Officers conducted regular checks without noticing issues. Blanchardâ€™s claim of alerting officers was deemed unreliable.
Legal_Framework: Prison authorities owe a duty of care to inmates, requiring reasonable measures to ensure health and safety. Liability arises if actions fall below the standard of a reasonably prudent person.

Credibility_Assessment: Blanchardâ€™s claim of alerting officers was deemed unreliable.
Legal_Provision: Prison authorities owe a duty of care to inmates, requiring reasonable measures to ensure health and safety. Liability arises if acts or omissions fall below the standard of a reasonably prudent person.
